descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Chinese Foreign Policy This course discusses the basic dynamics of Chinese foreign policy since the Nineteenth Century, with principal focus on the period since 1949 (and especially since 19880). Policy toward a variety of countries and regions and on a variety of issues (e.g. security, trade, development, etc.) will be covered, with some special emphasis on China's relations with the United States. Finally, we will examine China's foreign policy in comparison with that of other countries and explore implication for wider literatures and theories in IR and comparative politics.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: By the end of the course, students will be expected to know: 1) how foreign policy is debated and made in China; 2) what sorts of policies China has adopted toward a variety of countries over time and regarding various issues; 3) the basic results these policies have had; and 4) the idiosyncracies of Chinese foreign policy in comparison with other countries and the implications of broader theories and literatures.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: 5-6 in-class quizzes (20-25%), participation (30-35%), and final exam (45%).

descriptions.value: Attendance at first class required, No P/N Option
